title: 105_hr1289
content: The "Mammography Quality Standards Reauthorization Act" amends sections of the Public Health Service Act related to mammography quality standards and regulations. It updates authorization of appropriations and clarifies facilities' responsibility to retain mammogram records. Section 354(f)(1)(G) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to require facilities performing mammograms to maintain the records for at least 5 years, or 10 years if no additional mammograms are done, or longer if required by State law. The amended Section 354(f)(1)(G) of the Public Health Service Act requires facilities performing mammograms to maintain records for at least 5 years, or 10 years if no additional mammograms are done, or longer if required by State law. On behalf of the patient, forward the mammogram to a medical institution or physician of the patient. SEC. 5. SCOPE OF INSPECTIONS amended to include certification requirements under subsection (b) and compliance with. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF AUTHORITY TO DELEGATE INSPECTION RESPONSIBILITY TO LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. Section 354 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include local agencies in various subsections. Patient notification concerning health risks is emphasized. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include patient notification requirements for facilities with inconsistent mammography quality. The Secretary may require facilities to notify patients and referring physicians of risks and remedial measures. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include patient notification requirements for facilities with inconsistent mammography quality. Facilities must notify patients of risks as required by the Secretary. SEC. 8. REQUIREMENT TO COMPLY WITH INFORMATION REQUESTS. Amends the Public Health Service Act to include accreditation bodies in information requests. SEC. 9. ADJUSTMENT TO SEVERITY OF SANCTIONS. SEC. 9. ADJUSTMENT TO SEVERITY OF SANCTIONS. Amends the Public Health Service Act to adjust severity of sanctions based on intentional violations or serious risks to human health. SEC. 10. TECHNICAL AMENDMENT. Changes "accredited" to "certified" in the Public Health Service Act.
